member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PerlinNoise.Noise(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)

overloads.summary: Computes a noise value. Obsolete

member.summary: Computes a 3d noise value for a 3d position given by (x, y, z).
member.returns: The 3d noise value for the given position (x, y, z).

para.i: This method is obsolete. Use instead.

remarks.para: Perlin noise is consistent: For a constant position this method always returns the same noise value.
The noise should be in the range [-1, 1]. The noise value at integer positions is 0, for example Noise(11, 12, 13) = 0.
There is at max one oscillation (1 whole sine period) between two consecutive integer value.
Random values are generated per table lookup. Since the table is limited, the noise function repeats itself after 256 values: Noise(i, 0, 0) == Noise(i + 256, 0, 0)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PerlinNoise.Noise(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes a 3d noise value for a 3d position given by (x, y, z).
member.returns: The 3d noise value for the given position (x, y, z).

remarks.para: This method is obsolete. It is recommended to manually combine noise generated by the PerlinNoise.Compute methods as required. For example: .

A noise value is computed as in except that several noise functions with different frequencies (octaves) are added, for example for 3 octaves: noiseValue = Noise(x,y,z) + 1/2*Noise(2x, 2y, 2z) + 1/4*Noise(4x,4y,4z)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PrincipalComponentAnalysisD
member.summary: Performs a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) using the covariance method (double-precision).

remarks.para: This class takes a list of data points, computes the covariance matrix C and performs on the covariance matrix. The resulting eigenvectors represent the uncorrelated principal components of the data. The principal components ("natural axes") are the basis of a new coordinate system where the covariance matrix is a diagonal matrix. The first principal component is the direction where the variance of the data projected onto the principal component is greatest. The second greatest variance is on the second principal component, and so forth.

The matrix of the principal components () is an orthogonal matrix, with C = V * D * VT, where C is the covariance matrix and D is the diagonal covariance matrix in the space formed by the principal components.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PrincipalComponentAnalysisD.V
member.summary: Gets the matrix of the principal components.
member.value: The matrix of the principal components.
member.remarks: Each column in this matrix represents a principal component. Columns are ordered by decreasing variance.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PrincipalComponentAnalysisD.Variances
member.summary: Gets the variances.
member.value: The variances.
member.remarks: Each element in the vector represents the variance of the data points along a principle component. The variances are sorted by decreasing value, so that the largest variance is the first element.

member.param: The list of data points. All points must have the same .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.SphereDistribution
member.summary: A distribution that returns random positions from a spherical volume.

remarks.para: Two radii can be specified: and . These radii define a spherical shell. The method returns random positions from within this shell.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.SphereDistribution.Center
member.summary: Gets or sets the center of the sphere.
member.value: The center position. The default is (0, 0, 0).

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.SphereDistribution.InnerRadius
member.summary: Gets or sets the inner radius of the sphere.
member.value: The radius. The default is 0.
member.remarks: The and the define a spherical shell. Random values that are created are from the volume of this shell. If is 0 (default), random values from the whole sphere volume are created. If is equal to , all random positions lie on the surface of the sphere.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.SphereDistribution.OuterRadius
member.summary: Gets or sets the outer radius of the circle.
member.value: The outer radius. The default is 1.
member.remarks: The and the define a spherical shell. Random values that are created are from the volume of this shell. If is 0 (default), random values from the whole sphere volume are created. If is equal to , all random positions lie on the surface of the sphere.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.SphereDistribution.Scale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale factors that are multiplied to the random position.
member.value: The scale factors in x, y and z direction. The default value is (1, 1, 1).

remarks.para: A deque is similar to a queue except that objects can inserted and removed at both ends. The capacity of a is the number of elements the can hold. If is less than the capacity of the internal array, this method is an O(1) operation. If the internal array needs to be reallocated to accommodate the new element, this method becomes an O(n) operation, where n is .

member.summary: Copies the elements to a new array.
member.returns: A new array containing elements copied from the .

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Collections.Deque`1.TrimExcess
member.summary: Sets the capacity to the actual number of elements in the , if that number is less than 90 percent of current capacity.

remarks.para: This method can be used to minimize a collection's memory overhead if no new elements will be added to the collection. The cost of reallocating and copying a large can be considerable, however, so the method does nothing if the list is at more than 90 percent of capacity. This avoids incurring a large reallocation cost for a relatively small gain.
This method is an O(n) operation, where n is .
To reset a to its initial state, call the method before calling TrimExcess method. Trimming an empty sets the capacity of the to the default capacity.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Collections.PriorityQueue`1
member.summary: Represents a queue of values where the greatest item can be accessed quickly.
member.typeparam: The type of items in this collection.

remarks.para: This class implements a heap-based priority queue. Items can be added with (runtime complexity O(log n)). can be used to return the greatest item in the queue without removing the item (runtime complexity O(1)). returns the greatest item and also removes it from the queue (runtime complexity O(log n)).
Important: The enumerator (see ) returns the items in an arbitrary order - not sorted by priority!

remarks.para: This method resets this instance and returns it to a resource pool if resource pooling is enabled (see ResourcePool.Enabled).

member.name: T:DigitalRune.ResourcePool
member.summary: Manages a pool of reusable items (base implementation).

remarks.para: A resource pool can be used to remove load from the .NET garbage collector: Instead of allocating objects with new, objects are taken (see ) from a pool of objects when the are needed and returned (see ) when they are no longer needed.

It is safe to obtain multiple objects without recycling them. In this case the objects are simply collected by the .NET garbage collector. However, the benefits of resource pooling are lost. To achieve optimal performance all objects, which are taken from the resource pool, should be returned to the resource pool.

Performance Considerations: Resource pooling should only be applied if there is strong evidence that the .NET garbage collector poses a performance bottleneck. On platforms, such as Windows, with a generational garbage collector it is in most cases counterproductive to use a resource pool. By keeping a large pool of objects on the heap, the time of single garbage collection is increased and the overhead created by the resource pooling is worse than allocating objects in .NET with new. But on some platforms, for example the .NET Compact Framework on the Xbox 360, a resource pool can help to avoid frequent full collections by the garbage collector.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.ResourcePool.Enabled

member.value: if enabled; otherwise, .
member.remarks: This property can be set to to disable resource pooling globally. When disabled, the resource pools will always return newly allocated items.

remarks.para: Please read first, to learn more about resource pooling. The static class provides global pools for collections that are frequently used in the DigitalRune applications and libraries, but they can also be used in your application to avoid unnecessary memory allocations.
New resource pools may be added to in future releases of the DigitalRune libraries.
Thread-Safety: It is safe to access the resource pool from multiple threads simultaneously.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Threading.Parallel
member.summary: Provides support for parallel execution of tasks.

remarks.para: The namespace DigitalRune.Threading and the class provides support for concurrency to run multiple tasks in parallel and automatically balance work across all available processors. The implementation is a replacement for Microsoft's Task Parallel Library (see Task Parallelism (Task Parallel Library)) which is not yet supported by the .NET Compact Framework. This class provides a lightweight and cross-platform implementation (supported on Windows, Silverlight, Windows Phone 7, and Xbox 360).

The API has similarities to Microsoft's Task Parallel Library, but it is not identical. The names in the namespace DigitalRune.Threading conflict with the types of the namespace System.Threading.Tasks. This is on purpose as only one solution for concurrency should be used in an application. The library has been optimized for the .NET Compact Framework: Only the absolute minimum of memory is allocated at runtime.

The DigitalRune libraries, such as DigitalRune Geometry and DigitalRune Physics, /// make extensive use of the class . We highly recommend, that if you need support for multithreading in your application, you should take advantage of this class. (Using different solutions for concurrency can reduce performance.)

Tasks:
A task is an asynchronous operation which is started, for example, by calling . This method returns a handle of type . This handle can be used to query the status of the asynchronous operation (see ). The method can be called to wait until the operation has completed.

Futures (Task<T>):
A future is an asynchronous operation that returns a value. A future is created, for example, by calling and specifying a function that computes a value. The method returns a handle of type , which is similar to . The result of a future can be queried by calling . Note that can only be called once - the handle becomes invalid after the first call!

Background Tasks:
Long running operations which may block (i.e. wait for I/O operation to finish) should be scheduled as background tasks. Background tasks are created by using the method (or one of its overloads). Background tasks will not be scheduled using the (see below). Instead the class manages an additional pool of threads that are used for background tasks. The processor affinity of these threads is not set automatically. The background tasks will usually run on the same hardware thread where the background thread was created first or run last. The processor affinity can be set manually from within the task by calling Thread.SetProcessorAffinity.

Exception Handling:
The tasks executed asynchronously can raise exceptions. The exceptions are stored internally and a containing these exceptions is thrown when is called.

Completion Callbacks:
It is possible to specify a completion callbacks when starting a new tasks. For example, see method . The completion callbacks are executed after the corresponding tasks have completed. Completion callbacks are executed regardless of whether tasks have completed successfully or have thrown an exception.
However, the callbacks are not executed immediately! Instead, the method needs to be called manually - usually on the main thread - to invoke the callbacks.

Task Scheduling:
The number of threads used for parallelization is determined by the task scheduler (see ). The task scheduler creates a number of threads and distributes the tasks among these worker threads. The default task scheduler is a that creates one thread per CPU core on Windows and 3 threads on Xbox 360 (on the hardware threads 3, 4, and 5). The number of worker threads can be specified in the constructor of the .

The property can be changed at runtime. The default task scheduler can be replaced with another task scheduler (e.g. with a that uses a different number of tasks, or with a custom ). Replacing a task scheduler will affect all future tasks that have not yet been scheduled. However, it is highly recommended to use the default scheduler or specify the scheduler only once at the startup of the application.

Processor Affinity:
In the .NET Compact Framework for Xbox 360 the processor affinity determines the processors on which a thread runs. Setting the processor affinity in Windows has no effect.

The processor affinity is defined as an array using the property . Each entry in the array specifies the hardware thread that the corresponding worker thread will use. The default value is { 3, 4, 5, 1 }. The default task scheduler reads this array and assigns the worker threads to the specified hardware threads. (See also Thread.SetProcessorAffinity in the MSDN Library to find out more.)
Important: The processor affinity needs to be set before any parallel tasks are created or before a new is created. Changing the processor affinity afterwards has no effect.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Threading.Parallel.RunCallbacks
member.summary: Executes all task callbacks on a single thread.

remarks.para: It is possible to specify a completion callbacks when starting a new tasks. For example, see method . The completion callbacks are executed when the corresponding tasks have completed. However, the callbacks are not executed immediately! Instead, the method needs to be called manually to invoke the callbacks.
This method is not re-entrant. It is suggested to call the method only on the main thread.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Threading.Parallel.ProcessorAffinity
member.summary: Gets or sets the processor affinity of the worker threads.
member.value: The processor affinity of the worker threads. The default value is { 3, 4, 5, 1 }.

remarks.para: In the .NET Compact Framework for Xbox 360 the processor affinity determines the processors on which a thread runs.
Note: The processor affinity is only relevant in the .NET Compact Framework for Xbox 360. Setting the processor affinity has no effect in Windows!
Important: The processor affinity needs to be set before any parallel tasks are created. Changing the processor affinity afterwards has no effect.

member.exception: The specified array is empty or contains invalid values.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Threading.Parallel.ForEach``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Action{``0})
member.summary: Executes a for-each loop where each iteration can potentially occur in parallel with others.
member.typeparam: The type of item to iterate over.
member.param: The method to execute at each iteration. The item to process is supplied as the parameter.
member.remarks: The parallel foreach-loop has a few disadvantages: Enumerating the sequence in parallel requires locking. In addition, creating an object allocates memory on the managed heap. It is therefore recommended to use the parallel for-loop instead of the parallel for-each loop where possible.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Threading.WorkStealingQueue`1
member.summary: A special kind of queue in that it has two ends, and allows lock-free pushes and pops from one end ("private"), but requires synchronization from the other end ("public").
member.typeparam: The type of item stored in the queue.
member.remarks: This type of queue is usually own by a thread to queue work items or other resources. The thread can access its own queue without locking. A thread can access another thread's queue and try to steal items. Accessing the queue of another thread requires synchronization which is automatically handled by the queue.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Threading.WorkStealingQueue`1.IsEmpty
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this queue is empty.
member.value: if this queue is empty; otherwise, .

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Threading.WorkStealingQueue`1.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of items in the queue.
member.value: The number of items in the queue.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Threading.WorkStealingQueue`1.LocalPush(`0)
member.summary: Adds an item to the "private" end of the queue.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Threading.WorkStealingQueue`1.LocalPop(`0@)
member.summary: Tries to removes an item from the "private" end of the queue.
member.param: The item that is removed from the queue.
member.returns: if an item was successfully removed; otherwise, if the queue is empty.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Threading.WorkStealingQueue`1.TrySteal(`0@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Tries the steal an item from the "public" end of the queue.
member.param: The item removed from the queue.

The number of millisecond to wait for a lock. If the value equals , this method blocks until the lock is acquired. If the value equals 0, this method immediately returns without blocking if the lock cannot be acquired.
member.returns: if an item was successfully removed; otherwise, if the queue is empty.

member.summary: Represents an event that stores the target objects as weak references.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.WeakEventHandler.Register``2(``0,``1,System.Action{``0,System.EventHandler},System.Action{``0,System.EventHandler},System.Action{``1,System.Object,System.EventArgs})
member.summary: Registers an event handler that works with a weak reference to the target object.
member.typeparam: The type of the sender.
The type of the listener.
member.param: The object that provides the event.
The object that listens to the event.
A callback method that adds an event handler to the event.
A callback method that removes an event handler from the event.
A callback method that forwards the event to the actual event handler.
member.returns: An which can be used to detach the weak event handler from the event.
member.remarks: Access to the event and to the real event handler is done through lambda expressions. The code holds strong references to these expressions, so they must not capture any variables of the target object (listener)!

example.code: WeakEventHandler.Register( textDocument, this, (sender, eventHandler) => sender.Changed += eventHandler, (sender, eventHandler) => sender.Changed -= eventHandler, (listener, sender, eventArgs) => listener.OnDocumentChanged(sender, eventArgs));

member.name: M:DigitalRune.WeakEventHandler`2.Register``2(``0,``1,System.Func{System.EventHandler{`1},`0},System.Action{``0,`0},System.Action{``0,`0},System.Action{``1,System.Object,`1})
member.summary: Registers an event handler that works with a weak reference to the target object.
member.typeparam: The type of the sender.
The type of the listener.
member.param: The object that provides the event.
The object that listens to the event.
A function used to convert the given event handler to a delegate compatible with the underlying .NET event.
A callback method that adds an event handler to the event.
A callback method that removes an event handler from the event.
A callback method that forwards the event to the actual event handler.
member.returns: An which can be used to detach the weak event handler from the event.
member.remarks: Access to the event and to the real event handler is done through lambda expressions. The code holds strong references to these expressions, so they must not capture any variables of the target object (listener)!

example.code: WeakEventHandler<PropertyChangedEventHandler, PropertyChangedEventArgs>.Register( textDocument, this, handler => new PropertyChangedEventHandler(handler), (sender, pcHandler) => sender.PropertyChanged += pcHandler, (sender, pcHandler) => sender.PropertyChanged -= pcHandler, (listener, sender, eventArgs) => listener.OnDocumentChanged(sender, eventArgs));
